Award.AwardTitle: Planning a Dual Institution Research Center in Socially Relevant Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Morehouse and Spelman Colleges will plan and design a collaborative center in Socially Relevant Computing. The center will provide interdisciplinary education, research, and workforce development for African American undergraduate computer science students, particularly those who are at risk for degree completion. In addition, the center will create an ecosystem of partners to conduct research that leads to innovations to address critical societal problems of national priority and demonstrated interventions to increase the representation of African Americans in graduate school and the STEM workforce.

The principal investigators will implement the proposed project in multiple stages that include an internal assessment of capability and infrastructure requirements, an external assessment of relevant existing computer science centers for benchmarking, curriculum enhancements, and a pilot education research project to test an evidence-based socially relevant computing intervention concept. The project will help articulate strategies for developing degree pathways to increase persistence in computing for African Americans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At Spelman within the Computer and Information Sciences (CIS) department, we investigated the integration of socially relevant computing aspects into the curriculum. An external departmental assessment, concluded early in the project, recommended the updating of curriculum offerings in areas of socially relevant computing. This work exposed CIS faculty and computing students to the field. Curricular modifications were implemented in early computing courses, for those majoring in computer science and those majoring in other disciplines. A department-level coding assignment vault has become a significant outcome of these curricular modifications. This vault overs a breadth of computational thinking and algorithmic design concepts spanning four entry-level computer science courses in the curriculum. Given fluctuating teaching assignments, faculty now has access to a repository of nearly 250 assignments and many with corresponding solutions. These assignments are a mixture of course textbook problems and exercises vetted by the CIS faculty alongside assignments created and/or adapted by the CIS faculty. As of the 2018-2019 academic year, 227 students were exposed to at least one socially relevant computing assignment, of which roughly 150 students were not majoring in computer science. 

The department has experienced a nearly 25% increase in students majoring or minoring in computer science from 2016 to 2019, with the infusion of socially relevant computing as an important contributor. Nearly 75% of Spelman's computer science graduates proceeded directly to full-time employment securing full-time positions at Microsoft, NBCUniversal, Apple, Deloitte and so forth while the remaining are pursuing their graduate studies at research-intensive institutions such as Georgia Institute of Technology, Purdue University and New York University. New CIS faculty have been recently hired who factor in cultural relevance into their pedagogy and research. With these faculty additions, embedding of socially relevant computing concepts will continue and span the full spectrum of the department's course offerings.
